results.title: Yes, You Can Do Better Than the Great American Lawn
results.abstract: There are any number of ecologically friendly alternatives to that lawn you’re so proud of — and they look nice, too. Here’s how to start slowly.

media.caption: Low-growing wild strawberry (Fragaria virginiana) is one of the ecological horticulturist Daniel Jaffe Wilder’s favorite native lawn alternatives. It can withstand foot traffic, and the plants produce small, edible fruit.

results.title: Meet the Peecyclers. Their Idea to Help Farmers Is No. 1.
results.abstract: A shortage of chemical fertilizer, worsened by the war in Ukraine, has growers desperate. It just so happens that human urine has the very nutrients that crops need.

media.caption: A funnel for collecting urine in the home of Kate Lucy and Jon Sellers in Brattleboro, Vt.

results.adx_keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Restoration and Renovation;Palaces and Castles;Historic Buildings and Sites;DePree, Hopwood;Middleton (England);Great Britain
results.title: ‘Downton Shabby’: A Commoner Takes on an English Castle
results.abstract: A Los Angeles actor and producer moved across the pond to restore his crumbling ancestral home. But fixing up a 50,000-square-foot manor isn’t easy.

media.caption: “I first came to see the hall out of curiosity,” said Hopwood DePree, whose initial tour of his ancestral home, in 2013, included the morning room. He decided to stick around to bring the centuries-old property back to its early splendor.

results.title: Mark Shields, TV Pundit Known for His Sharp Wit, Dies at 85
results.abstract: A former campaign strategist, he became a fixture in American political journalism and punditry and was seen on “PBS NewsHour” for 33 years.

media.caption: The political commentator Mark Shields at his home in Chevy Chase, Md., in 2020. Politics had loomed large for him since he was a boy.

results.title: How Can You Travel for Less Than $100 a Day, Everything Included? Find a Cruise Deal.
results.abstract: As companies bring their full fleets back online, many ships still have room. That means bargains are being offered outside the winter “wave season,” making some sailings unexpectedly cheap, even in an era of inflation.

media.caption: Princess Cruises has much of its portfolio on sale through Aug. 31, including Alaska sailings, starting at $399 for a seven-day voyage.

results.title: Getting the Most Bang for Your Buck While Traveling Overseas
results.abstract: The strong American dollar is the upside of a volatile economy. For U.S. travelers headed abroad, that may help make up for the rising cost of travel.

media.caption: The dollar is soaring against many foreign currencies and that means that spending abroad is cheaper. A 100-euro rental apartment in Paris (above) that is $107 this summer would have been around $158 in 2008, when the dollar was weaker.
media.copyright: Joann Pai for The New York Times

results.title: Donald Pippin, Conductor on Broadway and Beyond, Dies at 95
results.abstract: As music director, he contributed to the success of acclaimed shows including “Oliver!,” “Mame,” “La Cage aux Folles” and “A Chorus Line.”

media.caption: Donald Pippin during the recording of the “La Cage aux Folles” cast album in 1983. He had more than two dozen Broadway credits, mostly as music director, and was a particular favorite of the composer and lyricist Jerry Herman.
